Ol such wrongful acts four have specific names and are called Delicts : Thelt (lurtum), Robbery (rapina), Injury to property (damnum), and wilful injury to the person or reputation (iniuria).

The precise differentia oi Delict, as compared with other forms ol legal wrong, and the reason why some ol these offences—notably Theft and Robbery-were ever treated by the Romans as civil wrongs at all, are topics upon which something is said in the commentary below. The text of the first Title deals with Thef. The delinition ol this, as the deliberately wrongiul dealing with (moveable) property, is con- trasted with our own English treatment oi the offence by its width and generality. It is Theft not merely to appropriate what one knows to belong to another, but to barely use a thing ol which one has under- talren the custody or which one holds in pledge, to turn what has been lent one to a use which it is not believed the lender would have sanc- tioned, or even to deprive another ol the possession of an object which one has delivered to him as security lor money owed.
